SourceText: Help your baby learn through play.  Put objects in your baby’s grasping hand, show them different materials, and answer when they ‘talk’ to you.

SourceText: Unfortunately, your baby will go through phases for the next 2 years of sleeping poorly. Try wearing your baby close to you, feeding them and carrying them in a sling. And hang in there, remember it’s a phase. You and your baby will get through it together!

SourceText: Your baby will cry as soon as a caregiver’s attention is diverted and are cranky as well as clingy. Prioritise being there for them and give them physical contact when needed.
text: Your baby will cry as soon as a caregiver’s attention is diverted and are cranky as well as clingy. Prioritise being there for them and give them physical contact when needed.

SourceText: Check to see why your baby is in a bad mood. Are they tired or hungry? Or maybe they are not feeling well? Or maybe they need some more loving attention. Be a reassuring presence for your baby when they are having a difficult day.
text: Check to see why your baby is in a bad mood. Are they tired or hungry? Or maybe they are not feeling well? Or maybe they need some more loving attention. Be a reassuring presence for your baby when they are having a difficult day.

SourceText: Remember that you’re in charge of what they eat, but not how much. Newborns have stomach the size of a grape! They need to eat often (sometimes in the middle of the night.
text: Remember that you’re in charge of what they eat, but not how much. Newborns have stomach the size of a grape! They need to eat often (sometimes in the middle of the night.

SourceText: It’s important to build trust around eating, especially as your baby starts on solid food. Let them know you are listening to their wishes in the eating department. They’ll be ravenous again soon!

SourceText: Pay close attention to your baby in case they try something dangerous! Just because they are able to play on their own now, doesn’t mean you can look away for long. Redirect mischievous behaviours into practice waving, imitation games, singing and moving games and pretending to talk on the phone!
text: Pay close attention to your baby in case they try something dangerous! Just because they are able to play on their own now, doesn’t mean you can look away for long. Redirect mischievous behaviours into practice waving, imitation games, singing and moving games and pretending to talk on the phone!

SourceText: Try to stay calm and support your toddler as they move through the tantrum. Your priority is to ensure that they don’t hurt themselves. Don’t add to your child’s anger by shouting and showing angry emotions. This won’t help.

SourceText: Babies are much more likely to want to do things if you make the activity fun and playful. Patience is also a must. Take a deep breath if you notice yourself getting frustrated by your baby.

SourceText: Your child will look to you for support and reassurance. Listen to your children when they share how they are feeling. Accept how they feel and give them comfort.
text: Your child will look to you for support and reassurance. Listen to your children when they share how they are feeling. Accept how they feel and give them comfort.

SourceText: When you share your own feelings with your children, you help them recognise their own feelings. It can also help your children learn self-discipline and to understand their own feelings.
text: When you share your own feelings with your children, you help them recognise their own feelings. It can also help your children learn self-discipline and to understand their own feelings.

SourceText: There are 6 basic emotions: Happy, Sad, Angry, Disgusted, Surprised, and Afraid. Even babies can feel and express these emotions. As children get older, they learn to identify lots of other emotions, like excited, frustrated, proud, lonely, peaceful, guilty, or confused.
text: There are 6 basic emotions: Happy, Sad, Angry, Disgusted, Surprised, and Afraid. Even babies can feel and express these emotions. As children get older, they learn to identify lots of other emotions, like excited, frustrated, proud, lonely, peaceful, guilty, or confused.

SourceText: It is normal to have difficulty talking about and expressing emotions and feelings. Many of us were told not to cry when we were sad or laugh when we were happy. This may be especially the case for boys and men.
text: It is normal to have difficulty talking about and expressing emotions and feelings. Many of us were told not to cry when we were sad or laugh when we were happy. This may be especially the case for boys and men.

SourceText: Talking about feelings can help children manage anger, disappointment, and frustration. It can also help your child be more aware of positive emotions such as a sense of peace, happiness, or calmness. It can also allow children to appreciate a beautiful moment or feeling of love!
text: Talking about feelings can help children manage anger, disappointment, and frustration. It can also help your child be more aware of positive emotions such as a sense of peace, happiness, or calmness. It can also allow children to appreciate a beautiful moment or feeling of love!

SourceText: Use physical and verbal support to make your child feel accepted and loved. A hug or saying, "I understand," can mean a lot. Remind your child that you are there for them and that they can always talk to you.
text: Use physical and verbal support to make your child feel accepted and loved. A hug or saying, "I understand," can mean a lot. Remind your child that you are there for them and that they can always talk to you.

SourceText: But we all have the same feelings, and  we can learn how to become aware of our own emotions, to experience them in our body, and to communicate about them.
text: But we all have the same feelings, and  we can learn how to become aware of our own emotions, to experience them in our body, and to communicate about them.

SourceText: Use consequences for refusing to follow instructions or forgetting household rules. Consequences help teach our children responsibility for what they do. They also allow discipline that is controlled. This is more effective than hitting or shouting.
text: Use consequences for refusing to follow instructions or forgetting household rules. Consequences help teach our children responsibility for what they do. They also allow discipline that is controlled. This is more effective than hitting or shouting.

SourceText: Children and teens often act disrespectfully or like they only care about themselves. Growing up is a difficult time when they are learning about who they are and how they want to be in the world. Luckily, there are other ways to discipline your teen without using violence…and they work well!
text: Children and teens often act disrespectfully or like they only care about themselves. Growing up is a difficult time when they are learning about who they are and how they want to be in the world. Luckily, there are other ways to discipline your teen without using violence…and they work well!

SourceText: Giving calm consequences help teach our children responsibility for what they do. They also allow discipline that is controlled. This is more effective than hitting or shouting.

SourceText: 3. Be realistic and follow through

SourceText: 1. Give your child a choice to follow your instruction before giving them the consequence.
text: 1. Give your child a choice to follow your instruction before giving them the consequence.

SourceText: 2. Try to stay calm but firm when giving the consequence.
text: 2. Try to stay calm but firm when giving the consequence.

SourceText: If you start yelling, it will just make things worse. Take a deep breath before you speak in a clear, calm, and firm voice.
text: If you start yelling, it will just make things worse. Take a deep breath before you speak in a clear, calm, and firm voice.

SourceText: Make sure you can follow through with the consequence. For example, taking away a teenager’s phone for a week is hard to enforce. Taking it away for one hour is more realistic.
text: Make sure you can follow through with the consequence. For example, taking away a teenager’s phone for a week is hard to enforce. Taking it away for one hour is more realistic.

SourceText: Consequences can also be used when your children forget a household rule, like going to bed at a certain hour or doing schoolwork before T.V.
text: Consequences can also be used when your children forget a household rule, like going to bed at a certain hour or doing schoolwork before T.V.

SourceText: 4. Reconnect afterwards.
text: 4. Reconnect afterwards.

SourceText: Once the consequence is over, give your child a chance to do something good, and praise them for it.
text: Once the consequence is over, give your child a chance to do something good, and praise them for it.

SourceText: For example, you can tell your child that if they do not do their schoolwork before dinner, they cannot watch their favourite T.V. show that evening.
text: For example, you can tell your child that if they do not do their schoolwork before dinner, they cannot watch their favourite T.V. show that evening.

SourceText: Using consequences can help children learn that their actions have an impact on themselves and others. It is an important step to prepare them for their life outside of the family as they get older.

SourceText: When our children share something that is especially troubling, we need to remember to stay calm, listen, and be open.

SourceText: Here are some things you can do when your teen shares something difficult with you:
text: Here are some things you can do when your teen shares something difficult with you:

SourceText: • Take a deep breath before you respond.
text: • Take a deep breath before you respond.

SourceText: • Listen to what your child is saying. Notice how they are feeling.
text: • Listen to what your child is saying. Notice how they are feeling.

SourceText: • Notice how you feel. Ask yourself, "What does my child need right now?"
text: • Notice how you feel. Ask yourself, "What does my child need right now?"

SourceText: • Reassure your child that you are there for them.
text: • Reassure your child that you are there for them.

SourceText: • You can deal with the consequences later but right now your child needs you.
text: • You can deal with the consequences later but right now your child needs you.

SourceText: • Discuss possible solutions or next steps to take action.
text: • Discuss possible solutions or next steps to take action.

SourceText: • Remind your child again that you love them and thank them for sharing with you.
text: • Remind your child again that you love them and thank them for sharing with you.

SourceText: The sound of a baby crying can be very distressing, especially for a parent. It is completely natural to want to make it stop. You might also think that you are not a good parent or that your baby is crying to spite you. But all babies cry. It is one of the main ways a baby can tell you that something is wrong.
text: The sound of a baby crying can be very distressing, especially for a parent. It is completely natural to want to make it stop. You might also think that you are not a good parent or that your baby is crying to spite you. But all babies cry. It is one of the main ways a baby can tell you that something is wrong.

SourceText: Here are some tips that might help when your baby cries:
text: Here are some tips that might help when your baby cries:

SourceText: 1. Why babies cry
text: 1. Why babies cry

SourceText: 2. Respond as soon as you can
text: 2. Respond as soon as you can

SourceText: 3. Check to see why your baby is crying
text: 3. Check to see why your baby is crying

SourceText: 4. Comfort your baby
text: 4. Comfort your baby

SourceText: 5. Take a break if you need it
text: 5. Take a break if you need it

SourceText: 6. Be gentle and patient with yourself
text: 6. Be gentle and patient with yourself

SourceText: 7. If you think your baby is injured or sick, call or visit a clinic
text: 7. If you think your baby is injured or sick, call or visit a clinic

SourceText: 1. Why do babies cry?
text: 1. Why do babies cry?

SourceText: Crying is a normal part of your baby's development. Sometimes babies even have crying patterns. Crying usually increases at 2-3 weeks old and is generally highest when your baby is around 6 to 8 weeks. Often babies will start crying less around 3 to 4 months. Of course, remember that every baby is different!
text: Crying is a normal part of your baby's development. Sometimes babies even have crying patterns. Crying usually increases at 2-3 weeks old and is generally highest when your baby is around 6 to 8 weeks. Often babies will start crying less around 3 to 4 months. Of course, remember that every baby is different!

SourceText: Go to your baby when you hear them crying. You will not spoil your baby by picking them up. Babies who are carried and cuddled frequently, during both fussy and contented periods, may actually cry less.
text: Go to your baby when you hear them crying. You will not spoil your baby by picking them up. Babies who are carried and cuddled frequently, during both fussy and contented periods, may actually cry less.

SourceText: 3.  Check to see why your baby is crying
text: 3.  Check to see why your baby is crying

SourceText: There are lots of reasons why babies cry. It might be hunger, pain, too much going on, rough handling, feeling cold/hot, wanting contact or attention, or feeling irritable. Babies can cry when they sense tension in the room. And sometimes they cry for no reason at all!
text: There are lots of reasons why babies cry. It might be hunger, pain, too much going on, rough handling, feeling cold/hot, wanting contact or attention, or feeling irritable. Babies can cry when they sense tension in the room. And sometimes they cry for no reason at all!

SourceText: Try swaddling, gently rocking, or singing or soft music. You might need to feed your baby or change their diaper. They may be too hot or too cold. Or maybe they just need to be held. Take a Pause and try to relax - your baby can actually sense tension from you, too!
text: Try swaddling, gently rocking, or singing or soft music. You might need to feed your baby or change their diaper. They may be too hot or too cold. Or maybe they just need to be held. Take a Pause and try to relax - your baby can actually sense tension from you, too!

SourceText: 5. Take a break!
text: 5. Take a break!

SourceText: If you are getting angry because your baby won’t stop crying, it’s OK to leave them on their back in a safe place and walk away for a bit. Check on your baby every 5-10 minutes.
text: If you are getting angry because your baby won’t stop crying, it’s OK to leave them on their back in a safe place and walk away for a bit. Check on your baby every 5-10 minutes.

SourceText: We know that this is not easy. You are not a bad parent if your baby continues to cry after you have done all they can to calm them. You are doing your best!
text: We know that this is not easy. You are not a bad parent if your baby continues to cry after you have done all they can to calm them. You are doing your best!

SourceText: If your baby cries for a long time and does not stop, they might be injured or sick. You should seek medical help immediately.
text: If your baby cries for a long time and does not stop, they might be injured or sick. You should seek medical help immediately.

SourceText: Call someone for help - a family member, a friend. Sometimes just talking with someone is enough, but if you feel overwhelmed, ask someone for help. Calling for help is a sign of strength.
text: Call someone for help - a family member, a friend. Sometimes just talking with someone is enough, but if you feel overwhelmed, ask someone for help. Calling for help is a sign of strength.

SourceText: Ignore negative attention seeking and demanding behaviours like whining or tantrums. Your child’s behaviour might at first get worse, but with time they will learn that it does not work. Be consistent and patient. And make sure that you are also giving your child plenty of positive attention at other times. You can do it!
text: Ignore negative attention seeking and demanding behaviours like whining or tantrums. Your child’s behaviour might at first get worse, but with time they will learn that it does not work. Be consistent and patient. And make sure that you are also giving your child plenty of positive attention at other times. You can do it!

SourceText: Here are 6 steps on how we can reduce negative attention seeking and demanding behaviours like tantrums using what we call Ignore:
text: Here are 6 steps on how we can reduce negative attention seeking and demanding behaviours like tantrums using what we call Ignore:

SourceText: 1. Try to redirect your child’s attention
text: 1. Try to redirect your child’s attention

SourceText: 2. Make sure it is a behaviour you can ignore
text: 2. Make sure it is a behaviour you can ignore

SourceText: 3. Ignore the behaviour not your child
text: 3. Ignore the behaviour not your child

SourceText: 4. Praise your child immediately for the next positive behaviour
text: 4. Praise your child immediately for the next positive behaviour

SourceText: 5. Be consistent when ignoring
text: 5. Be consistent when ignoring

SourceText: 6. Make sure you are giving your child plenty of positive attention at other times.

SourceText: Ignoring negative attention seeking and demanding behaviours is not easy. But if you are patient and give it time, it really works. You can do this!
text: Ignoring negative attention seeking and demanding behaviours is not easy. But if you are patient and give it time, it really works. You can do this!

SourceText: 1. Try to redirect your child's attention
text: 1. Try to redirect your child's attention

SourceText: When they start demanding for something or whining, first try to redirect them to a positive behaviour or activity. Praise them for that positive behaviour!
text: When they start demanding for something or whining, first try to redirect them to a positive behaviour or activity. Praise them for that positive behaviour!

SourceText: These are behaviours like whining, demanding, showing off, tantrums, and lots of other negative attention seeking and demanding behaviours that might make us think of the child as a bad child. But there are no bad children, only difficult behaviours!
text: These are behaviours like whining, demanding, showing off, tantrums, and lots of other negative attention seeking and demanding behaviours that might make us think of the child as a bad child. But there are no bad children, only difficult behaviours!

SourceText: 3. Ignore the behaviour not your child.
text: 3. Ignore the behaviour not your child.

SourceText: Ignoring behaviour means removing physical and verbal attention. You should still be aware of what your child is doing.
text: Ignoring behaviour means removing physical and verbal attention. You should still be aware of what your child is doing.

SourceText: When you ignore your child's behaviour (but not your child!), your child learns that the demanding behaviour will not work.
text: When you ignore your child's behaviour (but not your child!), your child learns that the demanding behaviour will not work.

SourceText: If we respond to these behaviours, our children learn that this behaviour will get them attention. They sometimes also learn that if they increase the demand, they will get their way.
text: If we respond to these behaviours, our children learn that this behaviour will get them attention. They sometimes also learn that if they increase the demand, they will get their way.

SourceText: This takes time AND patience. Normally your child will try to test you and behave worse. This is a good time to Take a Pause and Keep Calm.
text: This takes time AND patience. Normally your child will try to test you and behave worse. This is a good time to Take a Pause and Keep Calm.

SourceText: For example, if your child whines for sweets at the store, you might initially say “no” but then give in to your child when they start to have a tantrum. This happens to all of us!
text: For example, if your child whines for sweets at the store, you might initially say “no” but then give in to your child when they start to have a tantrum. This happens to all of us!

SourceText: Having a tantrum can be just as traumatic and difficult for your child as it is for you. Make sure you give your child plenty of positive attention and love as soon as they have calmed down.
text: Having a tantrum can be just as traumatic and difficult for your child as it is for you. Make sure you give your child plenty of positive attention and love as soon as they have calmed down.

SourceText: 6. Make sure you are giving your child plenty of positive attention at other times
text: 6. Make sure you are giving your child plenty of positive attention at other times

SourceText: Children need attention. If children get plenty of attention for just being themselves, as well as for the “good” things that they do, it helps them to feel good about themselves, and they do more of what they are asked.
text: Children need attention. If children get plenty of attention for just being themselves, as well as for the “good” things that they do, it helps them to feel good about themselves, and they do more of what they are asked.

SourceText: Your child's behaviour might continue to get worse.  It is important that you continue to ignore the behaviour.
text: Your child's behaviour might continue to get worse.  It is important that you continue to ignore the behaviour.

SourceText: Often, your child's response will grow more agitated when you start ignoring a specific behaviour as your child tries to test your resolve.
text: Often, your child's response will grow more agitated when you start ignoring a specific behaviour as your child tries to test your resolve.

SourceText: At this time, it is more important that you involve your child in a positive activity instead of talking about what just happened. You can do that later like at night or the next day. Right now your child needs love.
text: At this time, it is more important that you involve your child in a positive activity instead of talking about what just happened. You can do that later like at night or the next day. Right now your child needs love.

SourceText: If you find yourself ignoring your child's behaviour a lot, it is either because you are not being consistent (sometimes ignoring and sometimes giving in) OR you are not spending enough positive time with your child. One-on-One Time is super important!
text: If you find yourself ignoring your child's behaviour a lot, it is either because you are not being consistent (sometimes ignoring and sometimes giving in) OR you are not spending enough positive time with your child. One-on-One Time is super important!

SourceText: Try to remain consistent. Over time, your child will learn that the demanding behaviour no longer works.

SourceText: The first 1000 days of life are a window of opportunity for your baby. It is when their brain develops faster than any other time in their life. When you spend time with your baby, you build a healthy attachment between you both that will make them feel secure and loved.

SourceText: 1. Try to redirect your child's attention to something new when they demand something from you or are trying to get negative attention.

SourceText: Make a daily plan with your child for when they can spend time doing educational activities. This can include structured schoolwork and other activities online, reading, writing, or arts. Allow flexibility and time for play and relaxation too.

SourceText: Step 5. Support your child when they go back to school
text: Step 5. Support your child when they go back to school

SourceText: Tell your child that it is okay to feel scared or worried about going back to school. Allow your child to share how they are feeling. It is also normal if your child behaves different to their usual behaviour. Discuss how going to school might be different and how they can protect themselves from COVID-19. Ask them how their day went and support them if they experienced any difficulties.
text: Tell your child that it is okay to feel scared or worried about going back to school. Allow your child to share how they are feeling. It is also normal if your child behaves different to their usual behaviour. Discuss how going to school might be different and how they can protect themselves from COVID-19. Ask them how their day went and support them if they experienced any difficulties.

SourceText: Step 3. Remember that you are a parent NOT a substitute teacher!
text: Step 3. Remember that you are a parent NOT a substitute teacher!

SourceText: Your role is to support your child by creating a space to learn. You do not need to know all the answers. Help them explore their interests and ask questions. Go at your child's pace and be patient with yourself.

Parent groups or community groups can also be a good way to support each other with your home schooling.

SourceText: The idea of talking to children about abuse can be scary. We don't know what to say. But there are some simple things can help them understand when it is not OK to be touched, and that they can tell you if something ever happens.

SourceText: Here are 3 things that you should make sure your child knows to protect them from abuse:
text: Here are 3 things that you should make sure your child knows to protect them from abuse:

SourceText: 1. Learn about private parts
text: 1. Learn about private parts

SourceText: 2. Your body belongs to you
text: 2. Your body belongs to you

SourceText: 3. Bad secrets should be told
text: 3. Bad secrets should be told

SourceText: Type "1" to 3" to learn more about these tips. Type "N" to stop this tip.

SourceText: The parts of their body that go under people's underwear or a swimsuit are private parts. It is not OK for other people to touch or to ask to look at them, or ask them to look at or touch theirs.
text: The parts of their body that go under people's underwear or a swimsuit are private parts. It is not OK for other people to touch or to ask to look at them, or ask them to look at or touch theirs.

SourceText: If someone tries to touch your children's private parts they must say NO and tell a grown up that they trust.
text: If someone tries to touch your children's private parts they must say NO and tell a grown up that they trust.

SourceText: 3. Bad secrets should be told.
text: 3. Bad secrets should be told.

SourceText: Your children should tell you if there is a secret that makes them feel worried. You will not be angry. Only nice secrets - like a surprise birthday party - should be kept secret.

SourceText: Prevent anger from starting in the first place. Get some sleep or rest when you are tired. Try to eat something when you are hungry. Ask someone for support when you are feeling alone.

text: It can make you feel bad if your children do not want to spend One-on-One Time you. Think to yourself: When are they more open to you? Maybe in the morning or right before bedtime.

SourceText: Children often to want to spend time watching T.V. or playing with a gadget. Sometimes you might want to give them some other fun options to do instead (Type: "Help" if you want a suggestion).
text: Children often to want to spend time watching T.V. or playing with a gadget. Sometimes you might want to give them some other fun options to do instead (Type: "Help" if you want a suggestion).

SourceText: If your child wants to do things that are too difficult for you to physically do, you can simply watch your child. Try describing what they are doing like a sports announcer and praising what they do!
text: If your child wants to do things that are too difficult for you to physically do, you can simply watch your child. Try describing what they are doing like a sports announcer and praising what they do!

SourceText: Competitive games can be challenging for children (and adults!) if they have difficulty losing. You may want to suggest other activities that you can play together instead of against each other (Type "Help" if you want a suggestion").
text: Competitive games can be challenging for children (and adults!) if they have difficulty losing. You may want to suggest other activities that you can play together instead of against each other (Type "Help" if you want a suggestion").

SourceText: If your child is very young, it is normal for them to have a short attention span and want to do many things during One-on-One Time. Just accept your child and follow their lead moving from one activity to the next.
text: If your child is very young, it is normal for them to have a short attention span and want to do many things during One-on-One Time. Just accept your child and follow their lead moving from one activity to the next.

SourceText: You can also find something educational to do together with your child on the gadget. Or maybe ask your child to show you what is their favourite thing to do on the gadget. Just be patient. Soon they may open up to other activities, too!
text: You can also find something educational to do together with your child on the gadget. Or maybe ask your child to show you what is their favourite thing to do on the gadget. Just be patient. Soon they may open up to other activities, too!

SourceText: Sometimes our children will suggest activities that are violent or unsafe. Explain why they can't, and try suggesting alternative activities that would be more appropriate. Type "Help" if you want a suggestion.
text: Sometimes our children will suggest activities that are violent or unsafe. Explain why they can't, and try suggesting alternative activities that would be more appropriate. Type "Help" if you want a suggestion.

SourceText: You can also just sit next to your child while they are doing something they enjoy (like watching a T.V. show) and show them that you are interested in what they like. If you take their lead they will see that you care.
text: You can also just sit next to your child while they are doing something they enjoy (like watching a T.V. show) and show them that you are interested in what they like. If you take their lead they will see that you care.

SourceText: The end of One-on-One Time can sometimes be difficult for your child. Try giving your child a Transition Warning about a minute before the end of One-on-One Time: "In one minute, One-on-One Time will be over and it will be time to wash our hands before dinner..."
text: The end of One-on-One Time can sometimes be difficult for your child. Try giving your child a Transition Warning about a minute before the end of One-on-One Time: "In one minute, One-on-One Time will be over and it will be time to wash our hands before dinner..."

SourceText: It can be difficult to spend One-on-One Time with each one child when you have more than one child. If possible, you can ask another adult or older sibling to look after the other children while you spend One-on-One Time with one child.
text: It can be difficult to spend One-on-One Time with each one child when you have more than one child. If possible, you can ask another adult or older sibling to look after the other children while you spend One-on-One Time with one child.

SourceText: If your child is too young to understand how long a minute is, then you can set a number of time to repeat the activity: "5 more tries and then it will be time for wash our hands before dinner…"
text: If your child is too young to understand how long a minute is, then you can set a number of time to repeat the activity: "5 more tries and then it will be time for wash our hands before dinner…"

SourceText: You can also think of times when it would be easier to spend One-on-One Time each child, like later in the evening with an older child after the others have gone to sleep.
text: You can also think of times when it would be easier to spend One-on-One Time each child, like later in the evening with an older child after the others have gone to sleep.

SourceText: Only give the transition warning once. When One-on-One Time is over, thank your child for spending time with you. Then enthusiastically redirect your child to the next activity like washing hands before dinner.
text: Only give the transition warning once. When One-on-One Time is over, thank your child for spending time with you. Then enthusiastically redirect your child to the next activity like washing hands before dinner.

SourceText: You can also spend One-on-One Time with all of your children at once!
text: You can also spend One-on-One Time with all of your children at once!

SourceText: Type "Help" for activities that you can do as a whole family
text: Type "Help" for activities that you can do as a whole family

SourceText: We are glad to hear that. Remember, if you ever have any challenges, you can always type "Help" and we will try our best to help you out. Chat to you later!
text: We are glad to hear that. Remember, if you ever have any challenges, you can always type "Help" and we will try our best to help you out. Chat to you later!

SourceText: We are sorry to hear that this has not been helpful. Not all solutions work for everyone. Here are 6 steps that you can try to find a solution by yourself or with someone else:
text: We are sorry to hear that this has not been helpful. Not all solutions work for everyone. Here are 6 steps that you can try to find a solution by yourself or with someone else:

SourceText: 1. Take a deep breath.
text: 1. Take a deep breath.

SourceText: 2. Explore the challenge.
text: 2. Explore the challenge.

SourceText: 3. Think of possible solutions.
text: 3. Think of possible solutions.

SourceText: 4. Choose a solution
text: 4. Choose a solution

SourceText: 6. Reflect on whether it worked.
text: 6. Reflect on whether it worked.

SourceText: You should also praise yourself for trying. Parenting is not easy. You are a star just for showing up and caring. You can do it!
text: You should also praise yourself for trying. Parenting is not easy. You are a star just for showing up and caring. You can do it!

SourceText: Remember, if you ever have any challenges, you can always type "Help" and we will try our best to help you out. Chat to you later!
text: Remember, if you ever have any challenges, you can always type "Help" and we will try our best to help you out. Chat to you later!

SourceText: Hello! How are you doing? We are so happy that you have signed up to receive these messages. It shows you care.
